description.narrative: In the aftermath of Typhoon Yolanda the leadership of the Philippines Department of Social Welfare Development (DSWD) Region 6, and regional leadership of Adventist Development and Relief Agency (ADRA) and Adventist Community Services (ASC) have identified the existence of wide-spread post-traumatic stress injuries among typhoon survivors and those deployed to provide services. Collectively, these entities have requested that the Loma Linda University International Behavioral Health Trauma Team (LLUIBHTT) provide a 'train-the-trainer' program in the Community Resiliency Model (CRM) to address the need for sustainable skill development in the delivery of post trauma interventions for: 1) survivors of Typhoon Yolanda; and 2) workers and volunteers experiencing post-secondary trauma effects. As such, training has been requested for a total of 80 participants (i.e., 40 DSWD staff; 40 staff and volunteers from ADRA, ACS, and affiliate NGOs). The project goal, “To support sustainable skill development in post-trauma interventions for the survivors of Typhoon Yolanda”, addresses the need to develop an effective and expansive workforce capable of providing post-trauma interventions for survivors of Typhoon Yolanda now and in the future as individuals, families, and communities engage in redevelopment post-disaster.
